job_title: Associate Professor in Kansas City, KS

job_title: Administrative in Kansas City, KS
pros: Great group of people, supportive community, lots of positive things happening.
cons: High turnover and lack of trust in experts who are hired. Leadership does not let people do their job, lot of micromanaging.

pros: Lots of paid time off

job_title: Coordinator in Kansas City, KS

job_title: Admissions Recruiter in Kansas City, KS
pros: Family Environment in Admissions Department

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Kansas City, KS
pros: College invests time and energy into development of students and staff. Students have access to many resources. Lots of events where they feed you. High rates of graduation in the trades. School schedule!
cons: Insular, revolving door for younger employees, turnover so high no objectives are reached, zero follow through on grants, many programs begin, and very few finish. Weak in Managing, Strong in Status Quo.

review_title: Adjunct Professor Position in Public Speaking
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Kansas City, KS
pros: Students are eager to learn, though fearful of speaking in public. Some of them fear interpersonal communications as well.
cons: The fear of public speaking as well as the fear of interpersonal communications make it very difficult to communicate with modern-day students regarding any subject. They are distracted by technological advances our society has made in social media, communications, etc., and I have not yet identified a way to utilize these more sophisticated communication devices in the classroom.

job_title: Work Study in Kansas City, KS
pros: The office culture will vary on the department and particular person you work for you. I was in the Social Science, Education & Psychology Department and absolutely loved it. They were not only friendly and respectful to me personally but also encouraged and supported my academic successes.
cons: $7.50 an hour isn't much, but the flexibility to make your own schedule and not to have to commute to another location from school and work helps make up for it.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Dean and director were both easy to work with but serious about the academy. Respected boundaries, expected and nurtured excellence.
cons: The ratio of hours taught by adjuncts to fte was low. In the 5 years I taught, I believe there was only one FTE hire. LOTS of adjuncts came and left.

job_title: Intern in Kansas City, KS
pros: The IT department gave me the chance to work with them. I learned so much being hands-on in the field.
cons: Some employees thought that I should have been more knowledgeable and was not given the chance to perform duties.

review_title: A good job right out of college
